subject: statistics
title: Logistic Regression: Solving a Binary Classification Problem
contentHtml: In this example, we'll walk through a step-by-step solution to a binary classification problem using logistic regression.
problemHtml:
Suppose we're trying to predict whether a customer will purchase a product based on their age and income. We have the following data:
\[ \begin{array}{c|cc} & \text{Purchase} & \\ \hline \text{Age} & 25-34 & 35-44 \\ \hline \text{Income} & \$50,000-\$74,999 & \$75,000-\$99,999 \\ \hline \text{Purchase} & 0.6 & 0.8 \\ \end{array}\] What is the probability that a customer with age 35-44 and income $75,000-\$99,999 will purchase the product?",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the logistic regression model", "mathHtml": "\[ p(y=1|x) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(\beta_0 + \beta_1 x)}} \]", "explanation": "We're using a binary classification model to predict the probability of purchase given the customer's features."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Estimate the maximum likelihood estimates (MLEs) for the coefficients", "mathHtml": "\[ \hat{\beta}_0 = -1.23, \quad \hat{\beta}_1 = 0.05 \]", "explanation": "We're using the MLE method to estimate the model parameters."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Plug in the values for age and income", "mathHtml": "\[ p(y=1|x) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(\hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 \cdot 35-44)}} \]", "explanation": "We're plugging in the estimated coefficients and the customer's features."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Calculate the probability", "mathHtml": "\[ p(y=1|x) = 0.82 \]", "explanation": "We're using the logistic function to calculate the probability of purchase given the customer's features."} ],
intuition: Logistic regression provides a way to model binary classification problems by estimating the probability of an event occurring based on input features.

subject: statistics
title: Logistic Regression: Solving a Binary Classification Problem
contentHtml: In this example, we'll walk through solving a binary classification problem using logistic regression.
problemHtml:
Suppose we want to predict whether a customer will churn based on their usage patterns. We have the following data:
\[\begin{array}{c|cc} & \text{Churned} & \text{Did not Churn}\\ \hline \text{Usage 1} & 30 & 70\\ \text{Usage 2} & 20 & 80\\ \text{Usage 3} & 15 & 85\\ \end{array}\]",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the logistic regression model", "mathHtml": "\[p(y=1|x) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(\beta_0 + \beta_1 x)}}\]", "explanation": "This is the probability of a customer churning given their usage patterns."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Estimate the model parameters", "mathHtml": "\[p(y=1|x) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(\beta_0 + \beta_1 x)}}\]", "explanation": "We can use maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) to find the values of β0 and β1 that maximize the likelihood."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the odds ratio", "mathHtml": "\[OR = e^{\beta_1}\]", "explanation": "The odds ratio represents how much more likely a customer is to churn given an increase in usage."}, {"stepNumber": 4", "description": "Interpret the results", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "We can use the estimated model parameters and odds ratio to make predictions about new customers."} ],
finalAnswer: The predicted probability of a customer churning given their usage patterns." },
intuition: Logistic regression provides a way to model binary classification problems by modeling the log-odds.

subject: statistics
title: Logistic Regression: Binary Classification
contentHtml: In logistic regression, we model a binary response variable using a log-odds transformation.

problem.statementHtml:
A company wants to predict whether a customer will purchase a product based on their age and income. Given the following data:

  • Age: 25, Income: $50,000, Purchase: Yes
  • Age: 35, Income: $30,000, Purchase: No
  • ...
hints: Hint: Use the logistic function to model the probability of purchase
problem.solutionHtml:
We can use maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) to find the optimal coefficients \(\beta_0, \beta_1\). The MLE estimates are:

  • \(\hat{\beta}_0 = 2.5\)
  • \(\hat{\beta}_1 = -0.05\)

workedExample.problemHtml: A customer has an age of 30 and income $40,000. What is the predicted probability of purchase?

steps.explanation: We're using the logistic function to model the probability of purchase
We're calculating the log-odds by plugging in the values
We're applying the logistic function to get the predicted probability

intuition: The key insight is that logistic regression models the log-odds of the response variable, which allows us to make predictions and calculate odds ratios.

subject: statistics
title: Logistic Regression: Binary Classification
contentHtml: Logistic regression is a fundamental technique in machine learning and statistics.

workedExample.problemHtml:
Suppose we want to predict whether a customer will purchase a product based on their age, income, and education level. We have the following data:
  • Age: [25, 30, 35], Income: [$50k, $75k, $100k], Education: [HS, College, Master's]

steps.explanation: The logistic function maps any real-valued input to a value between 0 and 1.
The log-odds represent the logarithm of the odds in favor of the positive class.

steps.description: Estimate the model parameters using MLE
steps.explanation: The maximum likelihood estimate (MLE) is a popular method for estimating the model parameters.
The odds ratio (OR) represents the change in the log-odds for a one-unit change in the input feature.

workedExample.finalAnswer: The estimated model parameters and their interpretation

intuition: Logistic regression is a powerful tool for binary classification problems, allowing us to estimate the probability of an event occurring given certain features.
visualDescription: A diagram showing the logistic function and its relationship to the input data

subject: statistics
title: Logistic Regression: Solving a Binary Classification Problem
contentHtml: In this example, we'll walk through solving a binary classification problem using logistic regression.
problemHtml:
Suppose we want to predict whether a customer will purchase a product based on their age and income. We have the following data:
  • Age: 30-50
  • Income: $40,000-$80,000
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the logistic regression model", "mathHtml": "\[y = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(\beta_0 + \beta_1 x)}}\]", "explanation": "We're using a sigmoid function to map our input features to a probability."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Estimate the model parameters", "mathHtml": "\[logistic(y) = \frac{y}{n} + (1 - y)\ln(1 - y)\]", "explanation": "We're using maximum likelihood estimation to find the values of β0 and β1 that maximize the likelihood."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Interpret the model coefficients", "mathHtml": "\[OR = e^{\beta_1}\]", "explanation": "The odds ratio tells us how much more likely a customer is to purchase the product for every additional unit of income."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Make predictions using the model", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "We can use our estimated model to predict the probability of a customer purchasing the product given their age and income."} ],
intuition: Logistic regression provides a powerful way to model binary classification problems, allowing us to estimate the probability of an event occurring based on input features.
